DOC.HEAD: 600-foot Vessel Sinking 800 Miles from Hawaii
DOC.UNK: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with crew working to save ship, additional detail. Picks up 5th graf, `Anderson said....'
DOC.TEXT: A Chevron tanker pulled alongside a sinking freighter today that 28 crewmen were fighting to keep afloat in the North Pacific. The tanker delivered additional pumps to reverse the flow of water into two of the Bulka's cargo holds and stood by 800 miles northeast of Oahu to rescue the 600-foot scrap-metal carrier's crew if necessary, Coast Guard spokesman Keith Spangler said. Spangler said the Greek officers and Philippine crew were out of danger unless the ship sank rapidly. ``It seems to us they still have a chance to save the ship,'' Spangler said. ``It's just a wait-and-see game to see if the pumps will do it.'' One of the cargo holds was flooded and a second was filling rapidly, said Air Force Sgt. Neil Anderson of the Joint Rescue Coordination Center in Honolulu. The cause of the leak was unknown. ``The vessel is bowed down and listing slighting toward starboard,'' Anderson said. ``As it lists more as it fills up the crew probably will have to abandon ship.'' Spangler said the ship was listing 6 degrees to starboard and was down 15 feet at its bow. Anderson said the vessel was owned by a Greek shipping company based in Athens, Bacolitsas and Sons, but did not know if the ship was registered there. He said the ship was bound for either North or South Korea and was carrying scrap metal, but didn't know the tonnage. The tanker Chevron Colorado was diverted to the foundering vessel and passed three pumps to the Bulka this morning, Hubbard said. The Coast Guard cutter Sassafras was expected to reach the area Saturday. The crew, equipped with life vests and life rafts, was prepared to abandon ship if the pumping failed, Hubbard said. Winds in the area were 10 to 15 mph and seas were running about six feet, according to Roy Matsuda, marine forecaster at the National Weather Service office in Honolulu. A Coast Guard C-130 search and rescue airplane was on the scene and in radio contact with the Bulka, Hubbard said.
